title: Amazon Prime phone scam that swindled one victim out of £25,000
text:

A new Amazon Prime scam is doing the rounds across the UK, and honest Brits are being warned to watch out.

Circulating since earlier this month, the scam starts with unexpected phone call that claims you've just been charged for an Amazon Prime subscription, North Wales Live reports .

The recipient is often then told fraudsters have hacked their account to authorise the transaction, but the payment can be cancelled if they press 1.

People are told this will either offer you more information, or connect you to an "account manager".

These are fraudsters, some claiming to be technology expert who can undo the supposed hack if they're given access to your bank account.

A report in the Guardian said one elderly victim was conned out of £25,000 last month.

But what actually happens is that pressing 1 connects you to a premium rate number you then start paying for.

(Image: Getty Images)

Writing on Facebook , one recipient of the call, Dave Davies from Cheshire, explained: "Just had a call on my land-line telling me my bank account has been hacked and I am now paying into an Amazon prime account through direct debit and to cancel the payment to press 1 on the keyboard.

"I immediately hung up and checked my account online to see if said transaction had been processed to confirm that it had not, so definitely a SCAM. Be careful out there!"

One Twitter user posted: "Anyone else had a phone call from Amazon saying about renewing their Prime service? I'm assuming it's a scam."

Another said: "The latest scam call we had was a delightfully new one - 'Your Amazon account has been hacked and you have been subscribed to Amazon Prime. For more information, press 1'."

An Amazon spokesperson told North Wales Live: "We take phishing and spoofing attempts on our customers seriously, and will never call a customer for payment outside of our website."

They further advised customers to check the Amazon help pages if they have concerns or receive a call which they believe is not from Amazon.

Additionally, the Amazon website states: "If you receive a suspicious phone call claiming to be from Amazon and asking for payment or offering a refund you do not expect, please do not share any personal information, and disconnect immediately."

(Image: Getty)

An Action Fraud spokesman said: "The public have to subscribe to Amazon Prime themselves, and would not be automatically subscribed.

"If the public do receive this call and are worried that they were subscribed, the advice around this would be from UK Finance's 'Take Five to Stop Fraud' content."

This includes hanging up and contacting Amazon via a number or customer service line advertised on the genuine website - as they will be able to inform you if you are subscribed to Prime.

Action Fraud also reminded to never give out private information or details over the phone, especially in relation to bank accounts.

If you've already been the victim of fraudulent activity such as this, you should report it to Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040 or use their online fraud reporting tool .
description: Criminals tell unsuspecting people they've been subscribed to Amazon Prime - but can press 1 to cancel
